item.title: Issue #131 created
item.description:
Expression for binding the Context Value

When writing down the proposal in #129, I noticed we have no expression to bind a value to the context value. Such an expression would at least be helpful for formalizing new expressions based on the context (such as a fat arrow that binds sequences),

Here are two possible constructs for that:

1. Context Expression

ContextExpr  ::=  "context" "{" Expr "}" EnclosedExpr

(: Example :)
context { //flower } {
  count(.) || ' flowers: ' || string-join(./name, ', ')
}

The result of the first expression is the context, the second expression can reference the context.

A context-binding fat arrow expression U => { E } would be equivalent to context { U } { E }.

2. Enhanced FLWOR expression

Similar to variables, the dot could be used to bind and reference the context:

LetBinding  ::=  ("." | ("$" VarName)) TypeDeclaration? ":=" ExprSingle
ForBinding  ::=  ("." | ("$" VarName)) TypeDeclaration? AllowingEmpty? PositionalVar? "in" ExprSingle

(: Examples :)
let . := //flower
return count(.) || ' flowers: ' || string-join(name, ', ')

for . in //flower
let $name := string(name)
let $petals := string(petals)
return $name || ' has ' || $petals || ' petals'

A context-binding fat arrow expression U => { E } would be equivalent to let . := U return E.

Assessment

The first solution looks more promising to me. As FLWOR expressions are already very complex, weâ€™d probably need much time to understand all the implications. Next, people may argue that the advantage of FLWOR is readability, and that too many dots make expressions cryptic again.
